Future of Media

The Future of Computer Games

The project course “Future of Media” is a graduate-level course for master students at The Royal Institute of Technology (KTH) that study Media Technology and Media Management.

The course is held every year with different themes and this year’s theme is the “Future of Computer Games”. How can the computer games of the future look like and how can they be experienced in the future?

We are going to investigate ideas on topics such as gaming culture, human senses and technologies that will be used in the future. This will then be presented during an event the 16th of December where all project groups will showcase their findings. Representatives from the industry and around 200 students from different years and chapters will be invited.

About

Media Technology

Information, communication, media, and media technologies have become increasingly important in today’s society and in people’s everyday lives. Media technology can broadly be characterized as tech-nologies and methods for supporting communication between people across distances in time and space.

The KTH Royal Institute of Technology has offered a Master of Science in Media Technology since 1999.

Future of Media

In the project course “Future of Media”, advanced graduate students in Media Technology and Media Management explore the relationship between technology, economy and social factors in processes of technological innovation and development. The course load corresponds to a third of a semester and runs throughout the autumn semester. This year, 2016, the course is given for the fourteenth time, and for the sixth time in English, with international students participating.

A special effort is being made to document the work, and to make the outcomes of this course available online. The documentation will be included in a book, this website, as well as concrete practical “design representations”, such as movies and prototypes that have been created by different project groups within the course. The outcomes of previous courses are available in the archive.
